title: Watch 100 Years of Stop-Motion in 3 Minutes
text:
Sergio Pérez Gavilán — Feb 7 2017 
Screen grabs via author 
Since the advent of cinema more than 100 years ago, stop-motion has been a fundamental way of generating movement in inanimate objects. This technique gets a glorious homage from filmmaker Vugar Efendi in The Evolution of Stop-Motion , a video that shows the development of the technique from its first users to the present. 
The short film lasts three minutes and it is hypnotic in its display of stop-motion from such a range of creative eras. As a technique, stop-motion involves creating the illusion of movement an when object is moved in small increments between photographed frames, and then played back in sequence. 
It can make dolls dance, household appliances talk, or a toy circus come to life like it did in the film The Humpty Dumpty Circus (1897) the very first use of stop-motion in film. Efendi’s film starts in 1900 with The Enchanted Drawing and runs through the 2016 film Kubo and the Two Strings .
